snippet.textDisplay: I think owners and directors have a huge affect now. Liverpool are an example of having the best of both in terms of them having a plan and getting the best manager and players to act on that plan long term. Then you have teams like Arsenal and Manchester United who don't get the best managers or players to act on the plan, if they have a plan at all. Teams like Wolves, Sheffield United and Leicester have got long term plans to get into top 6 and shake it up. They get the players that suit their plan and get good coaches who can get the most Wolves got new owners in the championship and straight away made a ten year plan which was built on getting a manager who suited and invested into the plan and then they got the players who have the right mentality to be coached but also have the ability to carry out the short term goals.

snippet.textDisplay:
It can also be said that City are feeling the pressure from Liverpool's performance, which is leading to some stumble on their part (a la Liverpool last season, when City went on full throttle in the latter stages).

I totally agree that, apart from these 2 teams, the rest of the chasing pack is strictly mediocre, especially when it comes to teams that have made the top 6 historically.

This has changed the mindset of both sets of teams : a Chelsea can go into a match against a Newcastle, thinking that all 3 points are not assured. Conversely, a Newcastle can go into a match against a Chelsea, with the confidence that this is no longer a foregone result.

Having said that, the impact of coaches such a Rodgers and Wilder should not be underestimated - they are forming a legacy at the clubs they are currently associated with.

snippet.textDisplay: The only reason the "big clubs" aren't performing like big clubs this season is due to the talent distribution throughout the league, like Lawrence said. Every club has players that can win a match for them and you could probably go as far as to say that teams in 16th/17th/18th are just as good as the likes of Manchester united and arsenal. This league is the most level playing field its been since its creation apart from Liverpool of course. Anyone could beat anyone on any given day and that's not due to the lack of quality in the league, its due to the smaller clubs getting better and better as a result of TV money, prize money, attraction of the league that is involved in English football.

snippet.textDisplay: Think the answer is far bigger than that. We're going through a phase where the consequences of board mismanagement and poor set ups/not investing in youth are now showing. Mega clubs like Inter, AC, Madrid, United, Chelsea, Arsenal are all suffering so it's a question beyond the PL alone. The 'lesser' clubs are improving because of the way they are being run by those who have the clubs success and fans at the heart such as Wolves, Leicester, Sheffield where the board, the manager, the backroom staff and players are on the same page which isnt the case at the previous big clubs anymore.
snippet.textOriginal: Think the answer is far bigger than that. We're going through a phase where the consequences of board mismanagement and poor set ups/not investing in youth are now showing. snippet.textDisplay: The prem used to have the ‘big 4’ and everyone outside that was generally hopeless, nowadays there’s a ‘big 6’ but could even be a big 8 or 9 with Wolves, Leicester and Everton, any team can beat any team now because of the money in the league, it’s more competitive than ever, it’s just Liverpool and City are so good, Liverpool have come close to dropping points on numerous times this season and really had to grind out a result or get a last minute winner, the bottom 3 can take points off the top 3 no danger, teams finishing 3rd and 4th are collecting enough points to be in a title race in past seasons, the rest of the teams in the league caught up to the big 4 and then City and Liverpool created the big 2 and left the other 18 behind

snippet.textDisplay:
I’d argue that the competitiveness of the league in the past is being highly exaggerated. From the league’s formation to 1997 United were always the front runner with a different team challenging them each year (Blackburn, Newcastle etc.). Then Arsenal stepped up and challenged them year in year out for 7 years (97-04), before Chelsea put themselves into the conversation, and became United’s next challenger for 6 years (04-10), then City became United’s biggest rival for the last 3 years of Fergies reign.
United dominated for 20 years, and certainly had competition in Arsenal, Chelsea, and city for periods of time, but never constantly, so why was the quality of the league never questioned then?
Since then the title has went between the two big spenders in City and Chelsea for the past 7 years (Leicester aside), with City winning it 4 times and Chelsea 2 times.
The only time period in which the league was ever competitive to me was 2004 - 2009. In that period an English club made to the champions league final every year, producing 2 winners and an all English final. In the league, United were still the team to beat, but Chelsea, Arsenal, and Liverpool all genuinely challenged for the league at the same time, with all 4 having quality managers.
The quality of the league since 2010, to me at least, has been poor.
snippet.textOriginal:
I’d argue that the competitiveness of the league in the past is being highly exaggerated. From the league’s formation to 1997 United were always the front runner with a different team challenging them each year (Blackburn, Newcastle etc.). Then Arsenal stepped up and challenged them year in year out for 7 years (97-04), before Chelsea put themselves into the conversation, and became United’s next challenger for 6 years (04-10),  then City became United’s biggest rival for the last 3 years of Fergies reign. 
United dominated for 20 years, and certainly had competition in Arsenal, Chelsea, and city for periods of time, but never constantly, so why was the quality of the league never questioned then?
Since then the title has went between the two big spenders in City and Chelsea for the past 7 years (Leicester aside), with City winning it 4 times and Chelsea 2 times.
The only time period in which the league was ever competitive to me was 2004 - 2009. In that period an English club made to the champions league final every year, producing 2 winners and an all English final. In the league, United were still the team to beat, but Chelsea, Arsenal, and Liverpool all genuinely challenged for the league at the same time, with all 4 having quality managers.
The quality of the league since 2010, to me at least, has been poor.

snippet.textDisplay: I think United, Spurs and Chelsea have had a rough season so far and suddenly this is a massive concern for the premier league? Its 3 underperforming teams vs 11 up and coming teams in the moulds of leicester, sheffield etc and non-suprisingly the gap has closed. All.will be restored in the summer when united, spurs and chelsea raid all these "lesser" clubs for the players who have been actually performing this year. It's a constant cycle. Tops clubs sign players, players move on or get injured, lower teams come up strong, tops clubs raid.

snippet.textDisplay: Kills me to say it as a Man Utd fan but facts are facts and this Liverpool team are proper class and worse for me is they have an amazing manager and seem to be run how a football team should be run and for those reasons they really could dominate for a decade or more. I can't explain how much it hurts me, but, as a fan who went 26 years never seeing Man U win the tittle then got to watch the Fergie era I hope all of the Liverpool fans reading this really sit back and enjoy this moment that could/should be the start of something very special. As passionate fans our teams can sometimes ruin our whole day but that what makes it so special when everything you dreamed about comes to fruition and nobody can deny that on the whole Liverpool fans deserve what's coming their way even I get hairs standing up on back of my neck when I hear your never walk alone on the big European nights so take the time to appriciate what you have and make the most of it because I really hope that sooner rather than later my team can get it together and knock you back off that perch, again

snippet.textDisplay: So i dont watch the premier league often but i think the PL is actually better than ever, i mean a good league is defined by balance. And i think in the prem everybody can beat everybody (except Liverpool), thats why you find "good" teams in the mid of the table. I mean at the end of the day these are all professionals football players and even the "Bad" teams have really good players. So the average skill in the league increased tremendously. Please give credit to the "bad" teams instead of bashing the "good" teams for beeing historically bad.

snippet.textDisplay: This gave me a jolly good chuckle. Well done lads. I am a proud Liverpool supporter and they have knocked my socks off. Even when they are not performing up to standard they get the result. Does this make the other teams bad. Not really. I look at the lineups and see how much talent is in the squads. But not just the big team anymore. Across the board. That's why 3 points are not just a given anymore. That is why some of the big teams loose games they would normally win. Cause the talent and skill is more equally spread. Somewhere somehow Klopp and the Liverpool combination is just doing something special to be above the rest.

He’s made championship players comfortable in the premier league. Chelsea are not supposed to be an accomplished side we don’t have the Van Djik to bring it all together so stop talking about Liverpool players

snippet.textDisplay:
5 of the Top6 are playing dismally and for very specific reasons.

City - Lost Captain, injury problems.
Utd - Young Team, Injury Problems, Thin Squad. New manager.
Chelsea - Young Team, Transferban, Thin Squad. New manager.
Arsenal - Thin Squad. New manager.
Spurs - Injuries. New manager.

Also all these teams are in 4 competitions.

This causes inconsistencies and therefor lower teams can win games. Making a level league. Not taking away from Sheffields tactical brilliance.

Liverpool are the only team with a Prime Squad, Depth and no Manager or Leadership change ... allowing them to find consistency.

snippet.textDisplay: Kante isn’t having the best season, but he definitely isn’t as bad as some Chelsea fans are making out
snippet.textOriginal: Kante isn’t having the best season, but he definitely isn’t as bad as some Chelsea fans are making out

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry to say, but Geordie is very wrong here imo. It’s not that the level at the top has become higher, but rather that the league as a whole has become more competetive. Anyone can beat anyone. Before it used to be a clear difference between the top 4 teams and the rest, now it’s much more even. So the league as a whole has taken a step up, whilst teams like United and Arsenal have taken a step down.
snippet.textOriginal: Sorry to say, but Geordie is very wrong here imo. It’s not that the level at the top has become higher, but rather that the league as a whole has become more competetive. Anyone can beat anyone. Before it used to be a clear difference between the top 4 teams and the rest, now it’s much more even. So the league as a whole has taken a step up, whilst teams like United and Arsenal have taken a step down.

snippet.textDisplay: I think this is the best and most competitive the PL has been in ages. Liverpool are just an anomaly. Talent distribution wise everyone is very close except city who have the best and biggest squad around.
snippet.textOriginal: I think this is the best and most competitive the PL has been in ages. Liverpool are just an anomaly. Talent distribution wise everyone is very close except city who have the best and biggest squad around.

snippet.textDisplay: On the Kante point it’s simple as this Kante was and is great but in our system does not work except against the big teams. Don’t try and blame Lampard because Kovacic was a flop and this season hes been one of the best midfielders so Lampard has improved him immensely

snippet.textDisplay: It is the manager tho Rory I love Lampard he’s my hero but Sarri don’t it first by not playing him in his best position and Lampard is doing the same. If we want kante being kante then we need to play him by himself in a holding role with creative players around him.
